description: {"blocks":[{"key":"c5is4","text":"The most probable number (MPN) assay is a culture-dependent method of quantification most commonly used to enumerate microbes from environmental samples 1.  The MPN assay determines the density of microbes by serially diluting to extinction a sample in a medium which supports their growth.  Using probabilistic principles 2-4 , an MPN value is derived from the consecutive pattern of presence and absence of a measurable signal (e.g., optical density, fluorescence, luminescence), the original sample volume present at each dilution step, and the number of replicates for each dilution series.  Application of the MPN assay to a homogenous culture does not result in subjective interpretation of what is being enumerated in a sample. However, tracking a single microbe amongst an heterogenous population requires either complete suppression of non-targets or a mechanism of distinguishing the target within the sample. Here we provide a step-by-step protocol for the MPN assay using a fluorescently tagged soil pathogen and semi-selective media to estimate the concentration of targets from soil samples. To enable high-throughput screening, we perform the MPN assay in microplates 5,6. We refer to this assay as the MPN relative fluorescence units (MPN-RFU) microplate assay.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":153,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":323,"length":4},{"style":"sup","offset":1182,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"98htl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bn2a4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8vq1t","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6jdh7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4gll1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2ljs3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"4dg8d","text":"The estimated cell concentration obtained from an MPN assay is based on the probability theory.  There are assumptions that must be met in order for the MPN assay to estimate the true microbial concentration in a sample 1,4.  Assumption 1, the inoculum contains random distribution of microbial cells.  This means that at each dilution step, samples must be thoroughly mixed before proceeding with further dilutions.  Clumps prevent proper dilution of the sample leading to abnormal results with increasing dilutions.  Assumption 2, the presence of a single cell within a diluted sample should result in growth. Alternatively, serial dilutions and incubation can be carried out in a deep-well plate, and, at the time of data collection, samples transferred to a plate that meets the specifications of a plate reader.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":81,"length":22}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"49h73","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"tgpc","text":"We note that although well volume determines the path length and is correlated linearly to the intensity of fluorescence of each well, small differences in volume generally should not impact the determination of a positive sample.
